results.content: Very repetitious, little content despite all the talking and mouse pointing, limited and repeated sample data, anyone with any programming experience would understand his points in a fraction of the time he took,  each lesson covered only minor point. A good teacher could have combined 3 or 4 of his lectures into one without being too fast-paced. THIS WAS NOT EVEN WORTH THE TIME I SPENT WATCHING, much less having had to pay for it. I am very disappointed!

response.content: This is an introduction course and meant for beginners, so repetition of the main points would be expected.

results.content: Overall, a very good overview of JSON and how to use it. You'll need to have access to a HTTP server to properly run and explore all of the examples. A LOCALHOST or some other server will work. These are needed in order to access the JSON data files that are stored on your hard disk. The files are supplied as part of the course materials but you are responsible for setting up the environment.

results.content:
This is not a well-prepared course. The speaker should have used a script - it would have eliminated the many awkward pauses as he searched for what he wanted to say next or tried to find a way to correct something that he just said. Scripts can be very helpful for avoiding just that type of situation - as long as the person knows to read with inflection and not be robotic.

The other - and much more annoying factor - is a crutch I see WAY too many technical people lean on when they don't know what to do with their hands when speaking. THEY HIGHLIGHT, HIGHLIGHT, HIGHLIGHT with the darn cursor. This is a horrible habit! It's an indicator that the person has not thought out in advance what they're going to say and is instead just following their own train of thought that arises in the moment to drive the conversation. KEEP YOUR HANDS IN YOUR LAP. That is a great exercise when preparing to give a demonstration. It forces you to use your words and slow down instead of assuming (very wrongly) that the audience's mind pattern is the same as yours. It's most definitely NOT and you should never assume that's the case. It's horribly distracting and does nothing to assist in conveying the material.

response.content: The course presents topics outlined in the course description
response.content_html: The course presents topics outlined in the course description

results.content:
The course is informative as an *overview* of JSON (introducing arrays, etc.).. but if you're looking to learn how to code JSON from scratch, this is not the course for that. 

I am coding for Apple News (JSON) and unfortunately this does not help at all.

response.content: That's incorrect JSON is a data structure and not coded, the course does cover JSON and constructing JSON as it relates to JavaScript objects and arrays including different data types and how to structure it properly.  JSON, or JavaScript Object Notation, is a minimal, readable format for structuring data. It is used primarily to transmit data between a server and web application, as an alternative to XML.
response.content_html: That's incorrect JSON is a data structure and not coded, the course does cover JSON and constructing JSON as it relates to JavaScript objects and arrays including different data types and how to structure it properly.
